title: What Is Shrimp Posture & How Do You Fix It?

steps.title: Shrimp posture is a funny meme about sitting hunched over.
steps.content: Shrimp posture is a funny meme about sitting hunched over. Do you spend your time sitting at a desk or looking down at your phone? If so, it’s possible you’ve had shrimp posture before. Shrimp posture is when you sit with your shoulders rounded and your head dropped. This posture causes your back to curve, making you look like a shrimp. And while this posture is a silly online meme, it’s also a real thing that can be painful or harmful to your overall health. [1] X Research source What causes shrimp posture? Shrimp posture is most commonly caused by using electronic devices, such as cell phones and computers. Hunching over and looking down at a screen can negatively affect your posture over time. [2] X Research source Why is it called “shrimp posture”? When you sit with your shoulders and back rounded and your head down, your form looks very similar to a shrimp’s.

Shrimp posture started out as a meme on TikTok and has continued to take the internet by storm, becoming a playful but serious reminder to check your posture. Online creators have even made comic-style memes, skits, and merchandise to poke fun at their bad posture. “Shrimp posture meme” even has its own explore page on TikTok full of creative and entertaining content!

steps.title: Yes, shrimp posture can negatively affect your health.
steps.content: Yes, shrimp posture can negatively affect your health. Your posture plays a big part in your energy levels and overall wellness. If you have shrimp posture, you may experience back, neck, and shoulder pain. In severe cases, it can also increase the chances of arthritis. [3] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source \ Shrimp posture can lead to tech neck , a form of chronic neck or shoulder pain. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Look at your phone in an upright position.
steps.content: Look at your phone in an upright position. Looking down at your phone may be the cause of your shrimp posture. To avoid hunching over your phone, hold the device up higher so it’s at eye level. [5] X Research source We know this may not always be possible, so try limiting your screen time to see more improvements in your posture and overall health.

steps.title: Position your laptop or computer in front of you.
steps.content: Position your laptop or computer in front of you. One of the main causes of shrimp posture is looking down and typing on a computer. Here are some medically proven ways to improve your posture while using a computer or laptop: [6] X Research source Place your scream 20 to 30 inches (51 to 76 cm) away from your eyes. Use a computer monitor or laptop stand to raise the screen about 1 ⁄ 2 inch (1.3 cm) above eye level. Sit with your back straight and shoulders rolled back. Keep your wrists straight and your elbows bent at 90 degrees while typing. Keep your feet flat on the floor and knees aligned with your hips.

steps.title: Strengthen your back to avoid poor posture.
steps.content: Strengthen your back to avoid poor posture. Keep yourself from looking like a shrimp by improving your posture . These exercises and stretches can help alleviate shrimp posture and tech neck symptoms: [7] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Wall angels: Stand with your back against a wall with the back of your head, shoulder blades, hips, and legs touching the wall. Face your palms out and gaze forward as you slowly slide your arms up and down like you’re flying. Doorway lunge: Stand in an open doorway with your arms at your side bent at the elbows. Place your palms on either side of the doorway and lunge forward. Repeat for a few seconds on each leg. Shoulder blade push: Lie on your back with your knees bent and palms facing the ceiling. Push your shoulder blades down and back into the ground. Pelvic tilt: Lie on the floor with your arms at your sides. Round your pelvis forward, hold for a few seconds, then relax. Seated neck stretch: Sit up straight with your shoulders back. Hold the bottom of your chair with your right hand and lower your left ear to your left shoulder. Hold for a few seconds, then repeat on the other side, holding with your left hand and bringing your right ear to your right shoulder.

steps.title: Activate your core.
steps.content: Activate your core. Tightening your stomach muscles can help you straighten your posture and stay upright. Focus on your abdomen and slightly suck your stomach in to activate your core muscles. [8] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source This isn’t something you have to do all the time but try focusing on your core muscles every once in a while to check your posture.

steps.title: Wear comfortable shoes.
steps.content: Wear comfortable shoes. Believe it or not, what you wear on your feet can play a big part in your posture. Aim to wear shoes that are comfortable and well-fitting. Avoid shoes that force your feet and ankles into odd or uncomfortable positions. [9] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Opt for sneakers and wedge heels for the most support. [10] X Research source Now, this isn’t to say you can’t wear fun shoes every now and then! But aim to wear a comfortable, supportive shoe the majority of the time.

steps.title: Follow a healthy exercise regimen.
steps.content: Follow a healthy exercise regimen. Keeping your body strong and healthy is a great way to improve your posture. Aim to exercise at least 30 minutes every day—do something you enjoy! [11] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Something as simple as walking, dancing, or lifting a few weights can help strengthen your muscles so it’s easier to stand up straight. [12] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Stay mindful of your posture.
steps.content: Stay mindful of your posture. Being aware of your posture can help you correct it throughout the day. So, when you’re working, watching TV, checking your phone, or walking the dog, do a quick posture check. Roll your shoulders back and lift your chin to be parallel with the floor. [13] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source

steps.title: Good posture is when you stand or sit with your back straight.
steps.content: Good posture is when you stand or sit with your back straight. To have good posture , all you have to do is keep your head above your shoulders and hold your shoulders above your hips—it’s as easy as that! [14] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Simply roll your shoulders back and keep your chin parallel to the floor. [15] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source Keep in mind that there’s no such thing as “perfect posture.” Everyone’s bodies are different, and posture changes over time. As long as you aim to keep your back straight (however that may look for you), you’re golden.
